Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new subsection requiring eligible institutions to provide financial literacy counseling to borrowers. This counseling must be offered to first-time borrowers of loans through financial aid offices, designated employees, or partnerships with nonprofit organizations. The amendment to Section 485 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 requires eligible institutions to provide financial literacy counseling to first-time borrowers of loans under specific parts of the Act. The Higher Education Act of 1965 amendment mandates institutions to offer financial literacy counseling to first-time borrowers of certain loans, including counseling sessions totaling at least 4 hours for each occasion. Financial literacy counseling required for borrowers includes information on banking basics such as types of financial institutions, the usefulness of banks, and how to use checking and savings accounts. Financial literacy counseling covers budgeting, savings goals, credit card usage, and types of credit cards. Financial literacy counseling includes information on secured credit cards, responsible credit card use, building credit history, loans, grants, education tax credits, scholarships, differences between installment loans, grants, scholarships, and loans, repayment options for education loans. Financial literacy counseling covers topics such as renting, mortgages, credit scores, and investing. The Secretary encourages institutions to provide financial literacy information through interactive programs that test borrowers' understanding using simple language and clear formatting.
